Project Description  The Project will help meet the demand for high-quality treated 
water to the city of Harbin through 2010. The reservoir and head 
works  developed  by  the  Project  will  have  adequate  storage 
capacity to support a second phase of development sufficient to 
meet the needs through 2019. Harbin City, with over 3 million 
residents,  is  the  capital  of  Heilongjiang  Province  and  is  the 
seventh largest city in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
The Project will contribute to poverty reduction through provision 
of  water  supply  connections,  lifeline  tariffs,  increased  water 
supply  to  targeted  poor  areas,  and  employment  generation 
during its implementation and operation. Capacity building and 
training will assist implementation and increase efficiency in the 
Harbin  Municipal  Water  Supply  Construction  Company 
(HMWSCC)  and  the  Harbin  Municipal  Tap  Water  Company 
(HMTWC). 
 
Rationale  The Project will relieve a large deficit in supply capacity, estimated 
at 450,000 m3/day in 2005. The last major expansion in treatment 
capacity was completed in 1993. Since the mid-1980s, Harbin has 
been studying options and arranging the financing for a new clean 
water source. The proposed Mopanshan dam will be built in the 
upper reaches of the Lalin River, about 175 kilometers (km) from 
Harbin City. The Project was identified in the Government’s 10th 
Five-Year Plan (2001–2005) as a key water supply project and as 
a technically viable least-cost alternative to the continued reliance 
on the polluted Songhua River as a source of water for Harbin 
City. 
 
The Songhua River, the major existing source of raw water for the 
city of Harbin, is severely polluted by the discharge of untreated or 
partially  treated  wastewater  from  upstream  industries,  in 
Heilongjiang and Jilin provinces. The river, which flows through 
the Inner Mongolia Autonomous region and Jilin and Heilongjiang 
provinces and then into the Russian Federation, is contaminated 
with a number of trace organic chemicals, some metals, and 
conventional pollutants. The Government classifies its water as 
Class IV (declining to V–VI during the low-flow winter season), 
which  is  unsuitable  for  domestic  water  use.  The  river  water 
parameters  consistently  fail  to  meet  Class  III  standards,  the 
minimum quality required for the water to be used as a source for

water supply. A 3-year government research study project on 
chemical pollution in the Songhua, completed in March 2002, 
identified 191 trace organic chemicals in the river, of which 46 are 
known and suspected as causing serious health problems. The 
Government  is  taking  measures  to  decrease  pollution  in  the 
Songhua,  beginning  with  adoption  of  the  Songhua  Pollution 
Control Plan (expected to be approved by the State Council in

Use of existing public and self-supplied groundwater is depleting 
the aquifer beneath the city, resulting in land subsidence and 
damage to buildings. With the Project, wells will be placed on 
standby status, to meet maximum daily and emergency demands, 
and groundwater use will be limited to sustainable yields.  
 
Objectives and Scope  The main objectives of the Project are to (i) provide 450,000 
m3/day of clean water supply in Harbin; (ii) improve public health 
by  providing  clean  safe  water;  (iii) promote  long-term  urban 
development  in  Harbin  City  by  avoiding  water  shortages; 
(iv) provide  institutional  strengthening  of  HMWSCC  and 
HMTWC; and (v) use tariff reform to achieve full cost recovery.  
 
The  Project  scope  includes  (i) a  45-meter  high  dam  at 
Mopanshan with a reservoir volume of 356 million m3, a diversion 
tunnel and river outlet works, a water intake tower and raw water 
supply tunnel, and a gated spillway; (ii) a 175.5 km raw water 
pipeline  delivering  water  from  Mopanshan  dam  by  gravity  to 
Harbin; (iii) a 450,000 m3/day capacity water treatment plant; 
(iv) expansion and rehabilitation of the water distribution network, 
by installing 73.8 km of large pipes, 18 km of smaller pipes, and 
separation valves; and (v) capacity  building  of  HMWSCC  and 
HMTWC. As a result of the inundation of areas behind the dam, 
about  6,022  persons  (1,740  households)  will  be  relocated, 
mostly to host villages within the same county.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Harbin Water Supply Project. 
 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
2.  In line with its long-term goals for the urban sector of improving living conditions and 
expanding the supply of clean water, the Government of the PRC has requested the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to assist in increasing the supply of clean water to the city of Harbin. 
This report is based on the findings of the loan appraisal mission and discussions with central, 
national, and local government agencies concerned. The project framework is in Appendix 1 
and the project processing chronology in Appendix 2. Past ADB assistance to the PRC in the 
sector is given in Appendix 3.  
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.  Annual economic growth in the PRC has been 8% over the last 20 years and economic 
growth is projected at 7% over the next 5 years. The urbanization rate has increased to 36% 
and is expected to rise to at least 50% by 2030. This urbanization process will continue to 
increase the demand for all urban services. In particular, it will place a strain on the physical and 
financial capacity of most cities to provide adequate water infrastructure. Without significant 
investment, there will be a deterioration of the quality of life for urban residents, degradation of 
the urban environment, and inefficient economic development.  
4.  Municipal water supply in the PRC has increased steadily in the past decade. In 1999, 
total water production and sale were 26.8 billion m3/day and 22.8 billion m3/day, respectively, 
with unaccounted-for water (UFW) at 15% of total water production. The industrial and domestic 
water sales account for 35.5% and 55.3% of water sold respectively while other sales are 9.2%. 
The calculated national average use of water was 362 liters per capita per day (lpcd). Domestic 
consumption was 200 lpcd. In most large PRC cities, more than 90% of all urban households 
have access to piped water supply. However, this good coverage indicator obscures shortages 
in many cities of high-quality raw water supply, water supply delivery capacities, and wastewater 
treatment facilities. The Government has classified more than 300 cities as “water short”, with 
108 having serious water problems and more than 60 being critically short of water. The 
situation has been exacerbated by the pollution of raw water sources by the discharge of 
inadequately treated agricultural, municipal, and industrial wastewater.  
5.  The Government has recognized the severity of the water problem and identified the 
water  sector  as  one  of  the  priority  sectors  of  the  10th  Five-Year  Plan  (2001–2005). The 
Government’s strategy focuses on (i) developing water sources; (ii) protecting existing sources 
by controlling industrial and residential pollution; (iii) controlling overextraction from groundwater 
resources; (iv) introducing water-efficient technologies and operations; and (v) using appropriate 
pricing mechanisms to encourage conservation and generate necessary funds for operation, 
maintenance,  and  investment.  Government  guidelines  for  urban  water  supply  emphasize 
(i) proper planning, (ii) mobilizing financial resources for the construction of new facilities, (iii) full 
cost recovery from industrial and commercial users, (iv) recovery of at least operation and 
maintenance (O&M) costs from residential users with a movement toward full cost recovery, 
(iv) use of loans to finance urban water supply, and (v) application of new technology where 
appropriate. The Government’s ongoing economic and enterprise reform programs require that

all  water  supply  and  wastewater  projects  be  financially  sustainable  and  capable  of  cost 
recovery. The water supply sector analysis is given in Appendix 4. 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
6.  Harbin City is included in the Government’s list of 108 cities that have serious water 
problems. The proposed Project was identified in the Government’s 10th Five-Year Plan as a 
key water supply project and the technically viable least-cost alternative to the continued 
reliance on the polluted Songhua River as the source of water for Harbin. It is also considered a 
“key lifeline project” for Harbin City and Heilongjiang Province.  
7.  Key problems and opportunities include (i) unsatisfied demand for clean water in Harbin; 
(ii) pollution of the existing water sources, both surface and underground; (iii) land subsidence 
arising from the overuse of groundwater; and (iv) making water supply self-financing through 
tariff reforms and possible private sector partnership.  
1.  Background and Long-Term Plans for Songhua 
8.  The Songhua River basin is the third largest river basin in the PRC after the Chang 
(Yangtze) and Huang (Yellow) rivers. It has an area of 557,000 square kilometers (km2) and a 
population of 62 million. Major cities such as Harbin and Changchun, and the PRC’s largest oil 
fields are located in the basin. Agriculture is well developed and there is a large industrial base. 
The Songhua River catchment area covers portions of three provinces—Jilin and Heilongjiang 
provinces and the autonomous region of Inner Mongolia. After Harbin, the river joins the 
Heilongjiang River, enters the Russian Federation, and eventually discharges into the sea. 
9.  The Songhua River, the major existing source of raw water for the city of Harbin, is one 
of the most polluted among 47 major rivers in the PRC.1 The pollution is mainly because of the 
discharge of untreated or partially treated wastewater, primarily from industries upstream from 
Harbin. The Songhua River, which is contaminated with a number of known and suspected trace 
organic chemicals, metals, and conventional pollutants, is classified by the Government as 
Class IV2 (falling below Class V during the 6-month low-flow winter season), and is considered 
unsuitable for municipal domestic water use. The river water parameters consistently fail to 
meet PRC Class III standards, the minimum water quality required for the water to be used as a 
raw water source for water supply. Trace organic chemical pollution of the Songhua River was 
first reported in the early 1980s. A 3-year government research study completed in March 2002 
on  chemical  pollution  in  the  Songhua  River  and  associated  health  risks  supported  by 
international specialists identified 191 trace organic chemicals, of which 46 chemicals are 
known or suspected as causing serious health problems.3 The chemicals appear to be coming 
from petrochemical plants and agricultural areas upstream from Harbin. The government study 
indicated that trace organic chemicals detected in the water distributed indicated heightened 
health risks linked to consumption of Songhua River water. In recent years there have been a

10.  Existing public and self-supplied groundwater use is depleting the aquifer beneath the

11.  The Songhua Pollution Control Plan prepared by the State Environmental Protection 
Administration (SEPA), and expected to be approved by the State Council in March 2003, is the 
beginning of concrete steps needed to bring the Songhua River back to the minimum Class III 
water quality levels. The main objectives of the plan include (i) protecting the sources of urban 
drinking water supply; (ii) accelerating the construction of centralized treatment facilities for 
municipal sewage; (iii) controlling pollution from enterprises that have the largest pollution load 
and  volume  and  are  potentially  the  most  damaging  to  the  ecosystems;  (iv) strengthening 
ecological  construction  and  protection;  and  (v) strengthening  capacity  in  law  enforcement, 
monitoring, and research and information systems. The general water quality targets include 
improving  water  quality  in  the  mainstream  Songhua  and  key  tributaries  to  water  quality 
standards,  the  entire  Songhua  watershed  meeting  water  quality  standards  by  2015,  and 
ensuring  the  sustainable  utilization  of  water  resources.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  for 
Songhua River Water Quality and Pollution Control Management4 will assist the Government in 
refining the Songhua Pollution Control Plan and in finalizing the time-bound action plan for the 
clean-up of the Songhua River basin. The action plan will oblige compliance from the industrial, 
domestic, and nonpoint source polluters to the proposed actions through selected programs and 
priority investment projects, including those to be financed by ADB. In line with government 
policy, the TA will assist in undertaking a public information campaign on the health risks 
associated with Songhua River water pollution and help in mobilizing public support for cleaning 
up the Songhua River. The last major expansion in treatment capacity of Songhua River water 
intake and treatment facilities (250,000 m3/day) was completed in 1993. Further expansion of 
water supply is overdue, and Harbin is forecast to have a shortage in water supply capacity of at 
least 450,000 m3 /day in 2007, increasing to at least 950,000 m3/day by 2020.

4.  Water Tariff Reforms 
15.  During the era of the centrally planned economy, the provision of water was considered 
a basic social need and was heavily subsidized by the Government. Water tariffs in many cities 
remained unchanged for 20 to 40 years. As a result (i) water supply companies (WSCs) did not 
have sufficient financial resources to expand, or to operate and maintain existing systems in a 
financially sound manner; and (ii) consumers and industries had no market-oriented incentives 
to conserve water. Beginning in the mid-1980s, the need for tariff adjustments was recognized. 
Under the Government's ongoing market-based reforms, all WSCs and new water supply 
projects are required to be financially sustainable and capable of full cost recovery. WSCs are 
being  encouraged  to  corporatize  and  improve  their  cost-recovery  capability  and  financial 
sustainability. Between 1986 and 2001, there were major increases in water tariffs, averaging 
17% to 25% annually. Despite these increases, water tariffs are still relatively low.  
16.  ADB has supported the water supply tariff reform process through two completed water 
tariff studies11 with the Ministry of Construction. The first study assisted the Government in 
developing the National Guidelines on Water Tariffs (NGWT), focusing on improving the cost-
recovery performance of the WSCs and promoting water conservation and environmentally 
sustainable  use  of  water.  The  second  study  assisted  the  Government  in  developing  the 
institutional and methodological capacities to implement the NGWT tariffs and to set water 
tariffs. The impact of this TA will benefit all future ADB water supply projects in the PRC as tariff 
reforms and cost recovery are always on the policy dialogue agenda. The proposed Project is 
noteworthy as the first major water supply development in which the NGWT and the principle of 
funding investments directly from tariffs are being implemented in the PRC.  
17.  Tariff  and  other  reforms  have  created  opportunities  for  the  WSCs  to  improve 
sustainability by entering into joint ventures, by creating profitable subsidiary companies, and by 
seeking private sector partners to provide technical and financial assistance to undertake capital 
projects. However, government policy to encourage foreign investment in the sector and private 
sector participation in the water supply industry in the PRC is still at a very early stage of 
development. HMG, however, did take the initiative in searching for partners for the Project, 
although that effort was unsuccessful, and there remains the possibility of some private sector 
equity investment in the future.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits and Impacts 
43.  The Project will avoid water shortages and provide a safe clean source of water for 
Harbin, which presently relies on the heavily polluted Songhua River. In 2001, the five existing 
water works in Harbin operated over the year at 88% of capacity, and customer water demands 
could  not  be  met  during  peak  demand  periods.  Individual  facilities  operated  at  up  to  an 
unsustainable 118% of capacity on a monthly basis. Under the Project, the water supply will be 
increased by 450,000 m3/day, sufficient to meet maximum daily water demands after 2007. The 
proposed Mopanshan reservoir will provide sufficient yield to support future development of an 
additional 450,000 m3/day, which will meet forecast demands through 2019. When the project 
water starts to flow in 2008, separation of the distribution system will be completed, so that the 
dam water will supply the residential areas, and the Songhua River will serve the industrial 
areas. The proposed Project will serve 53% of domestic and other nonindustrial demands in 
Harbin in 2008.  
44.  Pollution in the Songhua River has reduced the existing raw water quality to less than 
the required Class III standard, and has  placed the population at risk from dangerous trace 
organic chemicals31 discharged upstream from Harbin that cannot be removed by the existing 
Harbin water treatment works. The Project will provide Harbin with a clean source of water 
supply, which will significantly improve the reliability and safety of the domestic water supply. 
Minimum flows from the dam will be no less than at present.

it will (i) be a properly constituted enterprise company, established under the provisions of PRC

C.  Social Dimensions 
1.   Land Acquisition and Resettlement 
46.  The Land Administration Law (articles 48 and 49) requires disclosure and consultation 
with affected persons (APs). The public consultation process for the Project began in 1997 with 
the initial asset inventory survey by the Hydraulic Design Institute. The Project has been 
publicized to the local population through the mass media, including local television. During 
project processing, site reconnaissance and surveys of affected households, host villages, 
village leaders, township leaders, and the project beneficiaries were completed. The public 
consultation process confirmed that the Project was welcomed by the local beneficiaries and 
many of the resettlers, who see relocation as the best way to improve their current living 
standards. 
47.  The construction of the Project will affect 1,740 households or 6,022 persons by land 
acquisition and resettlement. In total, 3,110 hectares (ha) of land will be acquired permanently 
and 650 ha temporarily. The total cost for both land acquisition and resettlement is estimated to 
be  CNY504.6 million  ($61.0 million).32  Resettlement  impacts  have  been  identified  and  a 
resettlement action plan (RAP; Supplementary Appendix C) and a summary RAP (Appendix 10) 
have  been  prepared,  addressing  issues  related  to  entitlements  of  APs.  The  resettlement 
information booklet (RIB) has been distributed to the APs, via village offices. The final revised 
RAP reflects feedback received. The full RAPs in Chinese and English have been posted at 
village offices. The RAP and the summary RAP have been posted on ADB's resettlement web 
site. Resettlement supervision milestones have been prepared to closely monitor progress on 
the resettlement actions. The Government, HMG, and HMWSCC will ensure that all APs are 
compensated in a timely manner and resettled in accordance with the RAP so that they will be 
at least as well off as they would have been without the Project. A mechanism was built for 
further consultation with APs throughout the resettlement process. There will be minimal effect 
on  indigenous  people  or  ethnic  minorities.  The  Project  includes  careful  monitoring  of  the 
resettlement  component  by  using  independent  international  experts  to  undertake  annual 
reviews  and  report  to  ADB.  ADB  consulting  services  include  a  3-year  resettlement  panel 
comprising two international and one domestic resettlement monitors (a total of 8 person-
months), who will visit the site yearly to review the progress made, the general welfare of those 
resettled, make recommendations to resolve any issues and support the training programs. The 
advisors will pay special attention to programs to help APs experiencing difficulties in regaining 
their preproject standards of living and report progress to HMWSCC, which will forward a copy 
to ADB.

D.  Financial Aspects   
50.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)  is  estimated  at  6.0%,  which  compares 
favorably with the weighted average cost of capital in real terms of 4.4%. Tariff increases are 
required to ensure the financial sustainability of HMWSCC. The sensitivity analysis included 
examination of the risk that costs would increase by 20%, or that revenues would be 24% less 
than anticipated; the resulting FIRRs are 3.6% and 2.3%, respectively. Detailed verification of 
the local financing plan indicated that the equity contribution from the city is about 1% of annual 
revenues,  indicating  minimal  risk.  HMG  has  sufficient  financial  resources  to  take  on 
responsibility  for  guaranteeing  the  loan  repayments,  and  has  provided  assurances  that  it 
accepts this risk. 
51.  An affordability analysis has been undertaken, based on proposed tariffs and household 
income data from the social survey. Tariffs under the Project are considered affordable if the 
combined average water and wastewater charges are less than 5% of household income. The 
estimated tariffs on this basis are affordable to the average household (less than 1% of income), 
and affordable to the poorest 10% of households (less than 3% of income). The risk that the 
proposed tariffs are not affordable is minimal, since the tariffs are within the affordability limit by 
a sufficient margin to allow for future wastewater tariffs. 
52.  The financial sustainability of the Project was verified through the financial analysis of

HMWSCC and secured through the signed water purchase agreement (WPA) with HMTWC. 
The financial projections for HMWSCC indicate that the minimum debt service coverage ratios 
and acceptable rates of return on equity included as loan covenants will be achieved by the 
Project. To ensure that the Project does not have an adverse fiscal impact on any level of 
government, wholesale and retail tariffs were structured on the basis of achieving full cost 
recovery for the Project. The overall fiscal impact resulting from the Project is expected to be

However, the shareholders and subsequently the guarantor of the ADB loan are assuming some 
financial risk during construction and the first few years of production. Based on the financial 
analysis these risks are manageable (Supplementary Appendix E). 
E.  Economic Aspects 
53.  The economic analysis was conducted for a 30-year period inclusive of the project 
construction period, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. 
Project benefits and costs were estimated on a without- and with-project basis appropriately 
apportioned on the basis of being tradable or nontradable, and with appropriate adjustments to 
the nonincremental and incremental project benefits. Incremental benefits were valued on the 
basis of willingness to pay. An estimation of health costs was undertaken and the effects of 
including relevant benefits are shown as incremental benefits.  
54.  A least-cost analysis comparing the Project with treatment of the Songhua River water to 
make its water at least comparable to the Project was performed.34 This showed that AWT by 
itself would have cost 8% less than the Project. The peer review desk study estimated AWT 
costs to be 1% less than the Project. However, there is uncertainty over the extent to which 
AWT water would still contain trace organic chemicals as indicated by the TA consultants and 
the peer review desk study. The economic analysis is discussed further in Appendix 12, which 
shows the levels of benefits (from decreased trace organic chemicals) required to raise the 
project economic internal rate of return (EIRR) versus AWT above 12%. Assuming that AWT 
water is the equal in other respects to project water (which is not certain), project water would 
have higher net benefit than AWT water if (i) people were willing to pay an additional $6 per 
person per year with the TA consultant’s estimates for AWT costs and $0.76 per person per year 
with the peer review estimates; or (ii) it decreased annual deaths, linked to consumption of the 
river water, by between 2% and 12%. 
55.  The EIRR of the Mopanshan system, including any benefits observed by consumers and 
for which they are willing to pay, is estimated at 12.6%. If only the benefits from decreased 
health risks to served persons to 2015 are included, the EIRR would increase to 18.2%. 
Sensitivity analysis indicates that the Project is slightly more sensitive to changes in benefits 
than costs.

G.  Project Risks 
58.  The Project does not have any unusual technical risks. The main dam is 45 m high and 
the earth-fill dam design is a sound and well-proven technology, with a high safety factor against 
failure. The Design Institute and the domestic project consultants have extensive experience 
with this type of dam. The TA international dam specialist concurred with the basic design. A 
panel of technical experts will be engaged by HMWSCC to conduct annual reviews on the 
technical aspects of implementation with provision of regular progress reports to ADB and 
HMWSCC throughout the 5-year construction period. The mechanical and electrical equipment 
associated with the Project are conventional and manufacturers/suppliers will be prequalified. 
The  ICB  equipment  package  will  include  technical  support  for  installation,  testing,  and 
commissioning as recommended by the manufacturer. In addition to the panel of technical 
experts, internationally experienced consultants will support project implementation. Based on 
the performance of ADB’s PRC portfolio, cost overruns and major implementation delays are not 
expected.  
59.  Potential risks in developing a strong water supply utility include (i) future constraints on 
institutional reforms, and (ii) lack of adequate public support to increase water supply tariffs to 
meet cost-recovery targets. These risks have been mitigated by (i) assurances from HMG on 
the financial and managerial autonomy of HMWSCC; and (ii) the diversity and frequency of 
public participation conducted to date, which HMWSCC is committed to continue, in combination 
with regular tariff reviews and oversight of local price bureaus. 
60.  Potential financial and commercial risks related to the project include (i) failure to meet 
the cash/equity transfers required to construct the Project; (ii) failure of HMTWC to honor the 
WPA; (iii) constraints on institutional reform of HMWSCC; and (iv) failure  by  HMWSCC  to 
increase the tariffs to meet cost-recovery targets. The potential financial and policy risks will be 
mitigated by assurances related to the financial and managerial autonomy for HMWSCC. ADB 
review  missions  will  monitor  HMWSCC’s  compliance  with  the  financial  and  operational 
covenants to ensure its financial sustainability. The risks associated with lack of local funding

will be addressed by having HMG pass a resolution that it would (i) meet whatever cost 
increases are incurred and (ii) provide a guarantee on the required equity injections to meet the 
financing requirements and financial ratios of the Project. HMWSCC will provide assurances on

up a debt service account with sufficient funds to cover 4 months of debt service payments

WATER SUPPLY SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Sector Profile 
 
1.  Growth in the urban population in the People’s Republic of China (PRC), from about 
190 million in 1980 to 456 million in 2000, excluding the growing “floating” population, and the 
number of cities from 136 in 1949 to more than 600 in 2001, has posed serious challenges for 
the supply of urban services. Rural to urban migration is expected to continue in the foreseeable 
future. About 700 million people, equivalent to 45% of the population, are expected to live in 
cities by 2010, which will result in rapid increases in the demand for water. An environment of 
increasing threats of pollution to water quality will exacerbate the problem, as will a shortage of 
raw water supply in some cities, and water supply delivery capacities and wastewater treatment 
facilities in many others.  
2.  During the era of the centrally planned economy, the provision of water was considered 
a basic social need and was heavily subsidized by the Government. Water tariffs in many cities 
remained unchanged for 20 to 40 years until, beginning in the mid-1980s, the need for tariff 
adjustments was recognized. Under the Government's ongoing market-based reforms, all water 
supply companies (WSCs) and new water supply projects, including those dealing with raw 
water supply delivery, are required to be financially sustainable and capable of full cost recovery. 
Between 1986 and 2001, increases in water tariffs averaged 17–25% annually but, due to 
concomitant income increases, in many if not all places tariffs remain affordable.  
3.  The Ministry of Water Resources is responsible for the planning and administration of 
water resources. The Ministry of Construction, through the provincial and municipal construction 
commissions, is responsible for overseeing urban plans and investments for cities. The State 
Environmental Protection Administration (SEPA) plays an important role in the development of 
sound environmental practices in the PRC water sector.  
4.  The  major  source  of  financing  continues  to  be  government  equity  and  grants 
supplemented  by  domestic  loans  and  official  development  assistance.  To  mobilize  the 
necessary domestic resources, the Government has created a tax-based water resources fund. 
Private sector participation in the water supply industry in the PRC is still at a very early stage of 
development. But the  Government recognizes that because of the large investments needed, 
greater efforts are required to mobilize private sector funding.  
5.  Water pollution remains a serious problem in most PRC cities. The Government has 
recognized that pollution of water resources is a major threat to sustainable development. The 
problem is being progressively tackled. Initial efforts were focused on industrial wastewater 
treatment but investment is also being made in municipal wastewater treatment.  
6.  The water sector continues to be a priority sector in the 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–
2005).  The  Government’s  strategy  focuses  on  (i) developing  water  sources;  (ii) protecting 
existing sources by controlling industrial and residential pollution in rivers, lakes, and reservoirs; 
(iii) controlling  overextraction  from  groundwater  resources;  and  (iv) improving  demand 
management by introducing water efficiency technologies and operations and using appropriate 
pricing mechanisms. Guidelines for urban water supply emphasize (i) proper planning and the 
inclusion of water supply projects in national, provincial, and municipal economic development 
plans; (ii) mobilizing financial resources from users and from various government sources for 
the construction of new facilities; (iii) full cost recovery from industrial and commercial users and

14.  ADB noted a report prepared by the World Commission on Dams5 and conducted a 
conference on the report in Manila in February 2001. The focus of the report is on improved 
consideration of environmental and human impacts into plans for development of dams, whether 
for irrigation, hydropower, or water supply. The strategic priorities identified in the report are: 
(i)  Gaining public acceptance: recognition of the rights and the need for informed 
participation of all stakeholders. 
(ii)  Comprehensive assessment of options: selection of projects by assessment of all 
relevant policy, institutional and technical options, as alternatives to dams. 
(iii)  Addressing existing dams: adaptation to changing circumstances over the useful 
life of a project, including social issues.  
(iv)  Sustaining rivers and livelihoods: minimizing the negative impacts on the health 
and integrity of river systems.  
(v)  Recognizing entitlements and sharing benefits: assuring the accountability of the 
dam owner or government to agreed provisions on resettlement, mitigation and 
development.

(vii)  Sharing of rivers for peace, development, and security.

POLICY DIALOGUE 
A.  Poverty Reduction 
 
1.  Harbin Municipal Government (HMG) has noted that poverty reduction is an overarching 
objective of ADB.  The results of a recently completed ADB technical assistance study on urban 
poverty in the PRC1 were discussed with HMG and HMWSCC. The purpose of the study was to 
assist the Government in developing an analytical framework for addressing increasing urban 
poverty. To achieve this, the objectives of the study were to (i) estimate urban poverty and 
validate the statistical findings, and (ii) provide recommendations for implementing the analytical 
framework. It was agreed that the framework would complement the ongoing poverty reduction 
efforts of HMG. 
2.  Discussions with the Harbin Price Bureau indicate an awareness of the need to protect 
the poor from these adverse impacts of increased utility charges. Those living below the poverty 
line have been exempted from the most recent price increase in water supply charges. These 
customers pay a reduced tariff of CNY1.3/m3, as applied prior to December 2001, on showing 
Harbin Municipal Tap Water Company a certificate from the Civil Affairs Bureau to confirm their 
eligibility. Broader discussions reveal that all levels of government are aware of the links 
between poverty, unemployment, and social unrest. Continued economic growth and reform of 
the social security system are two of the principal policy objectives being pursued. Availability of 
an adequate water supply is a necessary condition for economic development and growth.  
B.  Cost Recovery/Tariff Reform 
 
3.  The Project will support the Government’s ongoing economic and enterprise reform 
programs that require all water supply projects to be financially sustainable and capable of cost 
recovery.  Water  supply  companies  (WSCs)  are  required  to  improve  their  cost-recovery 
capability. Appropriate mechanisms for tariff setting are a critical factor in attracting the needed 
investment  to  the  sector,  ending  WSC  reliance  on  government  subsidies  and  providing 
incentives to users to conserve water resources.  
4.  ADB is actively encouraging this transition in its policy dialogue and lending operations. 
Two ADB water tariff studies supported the Government’s initiatives, the first by assisting with 
the development of national guidelines for appropriate tariff mechanisms at the national level, 
including the National Guidelines on Water Tariffs (NGWT). The NGWT was promulgated by the 
State Development Planning Commission and Ministry of Construction in September 1998 and 
will become fully operational by 2003. The NGWT is the first national regulation on water tariffs 
and also the first national tariff regulation within the urban public utilities sector. Stipulations in 
the  NGWT  cover  tariff  definitions,  tariff  setting,  application  and  approval  procedures, 
supervision, and monitoring. Tariffs are to recover costs, fees, taxes, and profits; wastewater 
treatment fees are included as an addition to the tariff and collected with the water bill. The 
NGWT provides a reference level for profit, based on source of funds. Tariffs should be set 
following the principles of cost recovery, a reasonable profit, water conservation, and fairness to 
users. The tariff application and approval procedures also include mandatory public hearings 
while the authority to approve new water tariffs lies within the concerned municipal government; 
these are a major step in improving governance in the water and wastewater sectors. The ADB-
financed second water tariff study focused on implementing the NGWT at the municipal and 
provincial government levels, and provided assistance in (i) drafting the local implementing 
regulations  under  the  NGWT,  (ii) setting  and  approving  water  tariffs  following  the  NGWT,

governed by a board of directors that will be responsible for overseeing all financial and

5.  The primary objective of the land acquisition and resettlement program is to ensure that 
affected persons (APs) will improve their standards of living, or at least not be made worse off 
because of the Project. This objective is consistent with the laws and regulations of the PRC 
and ADB’s policy on involuntary resettlement. The RAP is based on the provisions of the Land

(iv) Household  Registration  System;  (v) Administration  System  of  Registered  Permanent 
Residence;  (vi) Policy  on  Residential  Status  Transference;  (vii) Water  Law  of  the  PRC, 
promulgated in 1998; (viii) Environmental Protection Law of the PRC, promulgated in 1997; and 
(ix)  Land  Acquisition  and  Resettlement  Regulation  of  Large-  and  Medium-  Hydro  Power 
Engineering Construction, 1991. 
 
D.  Compensation and Entitlements 
 
6.  To ensure that the affected households and individuals can restore or improve their 
livelihoods and living standards, adequate compensation and rehabilitation will be provided. The 
compensation rates will follow the provisions of the Land Administration Law of the PRC, 1998, 
which  sets  the  minimum  of  land  compensation  and  relocation  allowance  for  all  types  of 
agricultural land at 10 times the annual average output value (AAOV) in the past 3 years. 
Compensation  rates  will  be  CNY78,000/ha  for  dry  land,  CNY118,000/ha  for  rice  land, 
CNY210,000/ha for fishponds, CNY216,000/ha for orchard land, CNY40,000/ha for forestland, 
and  CNY31,200/ha  for  homestead.  For  permanent  loss  of  land,  the  compensation  and 
resettlement allowance will be paid through the resettlement office of each affected village and 
forest station. These entities will distribute the land compensation and resettlement subsidy in 
cash to the individual APs. Any income lost from temporary land occupation will also be paid in 
cash directly to the APs at a rate of two times the AAOV. As soon as the construction is 
completed, the land will be returned to the users in its original form.

houses will be paid in cash directly to the owners, in compliance with the provincial guidelines

uncertainties are thought to be too large to enable a reasonable quantitative assessment of 
project versus AWT health benefits.  Instead, an approach outlined in ERD Technical Note 
No. 13 has been used. This note presents a method to calculate the required benefit per person 
served in order to raise the EIRR to the cut-off point, assumed to be 12%. Essentially, the 
method divides the additional net present value required by the number of persons served, 
discounted at 12% over the period during which benefits will be obtained. A similar method can 
also be used to estimate the required number of deaths saved before the river is cleaned of 
pollutants. This does require a quantified value to give for a statistical life and estimates based 
on both willingness to pay and productivity are given.  
11.  In addition to the quantified benefits there are also other possible unquantified benefits 
from the Project. These include (i) construction opportunities in areas where there are few at 
present; (ii) tourism and resulting employment generation at the reservoir site; (iii) stabilization 
of flows in the Lalin River that might increase irrigation and flood control possibilities; and 
(iv) diversification of supply, decreasing risks from drought or calamity (through the introduction 
of extremely hazardous wastes into the Songhua).  
 
E.    Least-Cost Analysis 
12.  There have been advances in treatment technology since the decision to exclude the 
Songhua was made. For that reason, ADB and the TA consultants felt it necessary to evaluate 
possible alternatives using that river. This least-cost analysis does not have the support of the 
project proponents, who do not consider the Songhua sufficiently clean to be an alternative to 
the Project. The alternatives that were considered were:  
(i)  conventional water treatment plant  
(ii)  advanced water treatment plant  
(ii)  full advanced water treatment plant  
 
13.  The purpose of least-cost analysis is to allow simple choices between projects that 
would provide the same, or at least similar, benefits. It should not be used by itself as a 
sufficient basis for comparison between projects that are known to have different benefits. For 
this reason, it is necessary to evaluate each of the alternatives for comparative benefits as well 
as costs. 
14.  Conventional water treatment plant, even if backed by household boiling of water, would 
not remove all known pollutants in the Songhua water. These pollutants would best be removed 
at source and this would probably be the least-cost solution. There are many relevant point 
sources, however, the most important of which are not under the direct control of the local 
and/or provincial government. In addition, certain of the trace organic chemicals previously 
released are now deposited in the riverbed and would continue to be released even if the

First, a small number of households (2.2%) use bottled water in the home at present. More 
importantly, convincing nonusing households of the need to do so would require the publication

the fact that boiling the water (e.g., to make tea) will not eliminate them. Second, is the effect of

high-rise apartments in these conditions is hardly an option.

18.  Project and Songhua AWT water might differ in two possible ways. First is  observed
